key_insight: The authors introduce PoseBench, a standardized benchmark that reveals current deep-learning protein–ligand docking methods perform well in many cases but have systematic failure modes (e.g., scoring, generalization, and flexible binding sites) that limit their reliability.
problem_solved: Lack of a comprehensive, standardized benchmark to rigorously evaluate and compare AI-based docking and structure-prediction methods across diverse proteins, ligands, and difficulty levels.
method: Constructed PoseBench: a curated, diverse dataset with labeled difficulty tiers and withheld test splits for fair evaluation.

Evaluated multiple state-of-the-art deep-learning docking and structure-prediction methods using standardized metrics (RMSD, success rate, ranking/scoring) and compared to classical docking baselines.
Performed systematic analyses of failure modes and case studies to identify factors (ligand flexibility, pocket dynamics, scoring) that degrade model performance.
impact: Provides the community with a clear, reproducible benchmark to guide development and evaluation of docking models; highlights concrete directions (better scoring, handling flexibility, improved generalization) where ML models must improve for practical drug-discovery use.
visual_elements: Dataset composition infographic: pie/bar charts showing protein families, ligand chemotypes, and difficulty tiers in PoseBench.
Performance comparison chart: grouped bar chart of RMSD and success rates for multiple AI and classical docking methods.
Error analysis scatterplot: prediction error vs. ligand size/flexibility or pocket RMSD to illustrate failure trends.
Side-by-side case studies: schematic images of experimental vs. predicted poses highlighting typical success and failure examples.
paper_title: Assessing the potential of deep learning for protein–ligand docking
paper_authors: Alex Morehead, Nabin Giri, Jian Liu, Pawan Neupane, Jianlin Cheng
